repo.description: Powerful Tox chat client that follows the Tox design guidelines.
repo.name: qTox

body: This makes it so we can simply compile all the files all the time, but the platform specific ones we don't need are no-ops. We're dropping libnotify here, so we're dependent on a system tray existing. Let's see if it's any good. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/TokTok/qTox/153)

comment_data.body: Why not? We want to give the user the ability to disable notifications at runtime.
Because all it does is return, and then we'll return regardless 2 lines later, having done nothing?
Ah, true. Well, it's outdated now, PTAL :).

You have changed `#include "src/platform/capslock.h"` to `#include "capslock.h"` in here (`src/platform/capslock_osx.cpp`), but kept it unchanged in `src/platform/capslock_win.cpp` and `src/platform/capslock_x11.cpp`.

Thanks, done.

The reason for this change is that later I want to use clang-format's header reordering. It needs the "current module" header to be in the current directory and a relative include.

It supports absolute includes as well. It's how I use it in in some of my projects. :P You can also set it up to bear the naming of your test files in mind when sorting to make sure that the header you're testing functions from is sorted at the top: https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormatStyleOptions.html#includeismainregex

commit.message:
cleanup: Simplify build scripts by using Qt system detection.

This makes it so we can simply compile all the files all the time, but
the platform specific ones we don't need are no-ops.

cleanup: Simplify build scripts by using Qt system detection.

This makes it so we can simply compile all the files all the time, but
the platform specific ones we don't need are no-ops.

commit.message:
feat: Add system tray notification support.

We're dropping libnotify here, so we're dependent on a system tray
existing. Let's see if it's any good.
